raw_text:
Remote control rifle range debuts
 
 Soon you could go hunting via the net.
 
 A Texas company is considering letting web users use a remote-controlled rifle to shoot down deer, antelope and wild pigs. For a small fee users will take control of a camera and rifle that they can use to spot and shoot the game animals as they roam around a 133-hectare Texas ranch. The Live-Shot website behind the scheme already lets people practise shooting at targets via the internet.
 
 John Underwood, the man behind the Live-Shot website, said the idea for the remote-control hunting came to him a year ago when he was watching deer via a webcam on another net site. "We were looking at a beautiful white-tail buck and my friend said 'If you just had a gun for that'. A little light bulb went off in my head," Mr Underwood told the Reuters news agency. A year's work and $10,000 has resulted in a remote-controlled rig on which sits a camera and .22 calibre rifle. Mr Underwood is planning to put one of these rigs in a concealed location in a small reserve on his Texas ranch and let people shoot at a variety of game animals. Also needed is a fast net connection so remote hunters can quickly track and aim at passing game animals with the camera and rifle rig. Each remote hunting session will cost $150 with additional fees for meat processing and taxidermy work. Species that can be shot will include barbary, Corsican and mouflon sheep, blackbuck antelope and wild pigs. Already the Live-Shot site lets people shoot 10 rounds at paper and silhouette targets for $5.95 for each 20-minute shooting session. For further fees, users can get the target they shot and a DVD recording of their session. Handlers oversee each shooting session and can stop the gun being fired if it is being aimed off-range or at something it should not be. Mr Underwood said that internet hunting could be popular with disabled hunters unable to get out in the woods or distant hunters who cannot afford a trip to Texas. In a statement the RSPCA said it had "grave concerns" about people being allowed to go online and remotely control a rifle. "We assume it would be extremely difficult to accurately control a gun in this way and therefore it would be difficult to ensure a 'clean kill', something the RSPCA accepts is the intention of those shooting for sport," it said. "Animals hit but not killed would without doubt be caused to suffer unnecessarily," said the statement. Mike Berger, wildlife director of the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, said current hunting statutes did not cover net or remote hunting. He said state laws on hunting only covered "regulated animals" such as native deer and bird species. As such there was nothing to stop Mr Underwood letting people hunt "unregulated" imported animals and wild pigs. Mr Underwood also lets people come in person to the ranch to hunt and shoot game animals.
llama3.2:1b: A Texas company is planning to let web users use a remote-controlled rifle to hunt deer, antelope, and wild pigs on a 133-hectare ranch. The service will allow users to take control of a camera and rifle via the internet for $150 per session, with additional fees for meat processing and taxidermy work. The company's founder, John Underwood, has already installed a remote-controlled rig at his Texas ranch and plans to let people hunt in secret locations there. However, other organizations have expressed concerns about the potential for inaccurate shooting and unnecessary animal suffering.
llama3.2:3b: A Texas company is planning to offer remote-controlled rifle hunting on a 133-hectare ranch for $150 per session, allowing users to control a camera and rifle to spot and shoot deer, antelope, and wild pigs. The Live-Shot website already allows people to practice shooting at targets online, and the company plans to add this feature with a fast net connection to track and aim at game animals in real-time.
gemma2:2b: A Texas company is offering online rifle range for a fee, where users can remotely shoot deer, antelope, and wild pigs on a Texas ranch. The service includes a live feed of game via camera and costs $150 per session. The RSPCA has expressed concerns about the accuracy and potential suffering of animals killed in this manner, but Mike Berger from the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department says current laws do not cover remote hunting.

Species like sheep and pigs can be hunted, but the RSPCA opposes net-based hunting, while wildlife officials allow it on their ranches.

Concerns have been raised by groups like the RSPCA about potential animal cruelty due to remote control hunting accuracy issues, while wildlife director Mike Berger of Texas Parks and Wildlife Department noted that existing laws do not cover such practices.

Okay, I need to summarize this text about remote-controlled rifle range hunting. Let me read through it carefully.

The main idea is that a Texas company is considering allowing people to use a remote-controlled rifle to shoot deer, antelope, and wild pigs via the internet. They're talking about an app called Live-Shot where users can practice shooting at targets online. 

Mr. John Underwood behind the project explains how he got interested—he saw deer on a webcam and thought it was like having a gun for hunting. He built a remote-controlled rig which costs $10,000 in fees, plus the cost of the camera and rifle. Each session is $150, with extra fees for meat or taxidermy.

There are restrictions: they need a fast net connection to track and aim at passing animals. They plan to set up a concealed reserve on their ranch. The app allows shooting 10 rounds at paper/silhouette targets for $5.95 each session. Handlers can stop the gun if it's off-range or aimed incorrectly.

The RSPCA is worried about allowing online hunting, saying it might be too difficult and could cause unnecessary harm to animals. Texas Parks and Wildlife says their laws don't cover net hunting either; they only regulate wild and managed wildlife. So underwood is trying to set up a remote option for those who can't get out or aren't on a budget.

I need to make sure I capture all the key points without adding my own words, keeping it concise as per the instructions.
</think>

Remote-controlled rifle range hunting begins in Texas, allowing users via the internet to shoot deer, antelope, and wild pigs. A Texas company, behind Mr. John Underwood, built a remote-control rig costing $10,000 plus fees for equipment. Each session costs $150 with extra fees, targeting 10 rounds at paper/silhouette targets for $5.95. They set up a concealed reserve on their ranch and need a fast net connection. RSPC warn about internet hunting's risks, while state laws don't cover net hunting, but underwood offers remote options for those who can't hunt locally.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Texas company is considering allowing web users to use a remote-controlled rifle to hunt deer, antelopes, and wild pigs. The Live-Shot website behind the scheme already lets people practise shooting at targets via the internet, but it plans to let people shoot a variety of game animals with the remote-controlled rig on a small ranch in Texas. In addition to hunting, users will be able to shoot paper and silhouette targets for $5.95 each 20-minute session, as well as get the target they shot and record their session for $150. The RSPCA (Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals) expressed grave concerns about remote hunting, stating that it would be difficult to ensure a "clean kill" without a "regulated animal". As such, Texas Parks and Wildlife Department director Mike Bergman said that state laws only covered "regulated animals", not unregulated imported ones. The company offers web-based hunts with the remote-controlled rifle for people from a nearby ranch.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The remote control hunting scheme is set to launch soon, with users being able to take part for a small fee that depends on how far away they want to go. This can be done through the internet, allowing those who cannot afford to visit Texas to try their luck while still being able to enjoy the convenience of having a gun at their fingertips. The remote control hunting system is being developed by John Underwood, with plans for it to be operational on his Texas ranch within a year. The scheme will allow users to hunt various types of game animals, such as deer, antelope and wild pigs, from a concealed location using a camera and rifle rig. Users will also have access to a fast internet connection, allowing them to quickly track and aim at passing game animals with the camera and rifle rig. The remote hunting sessions will cost $150 per session, with additional fees for meat processing, taxidermy work and target shooting. The proposed scheme has already been met with some skepticism from the RSPCA, who believe it would not be a "clean kill" and would allow hunters to hit but not kill wild animals without the need for an accurate gun. However, Mike Berger, wildlife director of the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, said that current hunting statutes only cover regulated animals and as such, state laws on hunting do not cover net or remote hunting.

Remote hunting sessions will cost $150, with additional fees for meat processing and taxidermy work. Only certain game animals can be shot, and handlers oversee each session to ensure accuracy. The RSPCA has expressed concern about the potential harm to animals, but the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department does not regulate net or remote hunting.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
A Texas entrepreneur, John Underwood, is developing a remote-controlled hunting system that allows internet users to control a camera and .22 calibre rifle, targeting various game animals like deer, antelope, wild pigs, sheep, blackbuck antelope, and wild pigs on his 133-hectare ranch. This concept originated from watching webcam footage of a white-tail buck and a friend's suggestion to equip it with a gun. The project, named Live-Shot, costs $150 per session, with additional fees for meat processing and taxidermy. Underwood plans to install the remote hunting rig in a concealed location on his ranch, ensuring handlers oversee each session to prevent off-range or improper target selection.

The RSPCA expresses serious concerns about this form of internet hunting, citing potential animal suffering due to inaccurate gun control and the difficulty of achieving a "clean kill." Mike Berger from the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department notes that current regulations do not cover remote or net hunting, leaving room for such activities on unregulated game. Underwood also offers traditional on-site hunting experiences at his ranch.
